title: Warren Gatland compares Sebastien Vahaamahina red card to Sam Warburton’s in 2011
text:
Gatland was in charge when a red card ruined Wales’ hopes in 2011 (Picture: Getty)

Warren Gatland could not help but see the similarities between Wales’ Rugby World Cup quarter-final victory over France and their 2011 exit from the same tournament.

Wales conceded three first-half tries but came back from 19-10 down after half-time to win 20-19, thanks in no small part to Sebastien Vahaamahina’s red card for deliberately elbowing Aaron Wainwright in the face.

It still took Wales until the dying minutes to get into the lead, Ross Moriarty going over from close range after Tomos Williams disrupted a wheeling French scrum.

Vahaamahina’s loose elbow was picked up by the TMO (Picture: ITV)

But the Dan Biggar conversion was enough to seal victory and coach Gatland could not help but smile.

‘It was the other way but similar to 2011 when we had the red card and we lost by a point,’ Gatland said with a twinkle in his eye.

‘It wasn’t the prettiest in the world but some great character shown.

‘We experienced [the galvanising effect of a red card on a team] in 2011 when Sam Warburton was sent off and we were disappointed we didn’t win the game from there.’

Warburton was dismissed inside the first 20 minutes for a tip-tackle eight years ago before Wales went on to lose 9-8.

But with Alun Wyn Jones at the helm, who played in that 2011 defeat, they avenged the defeat against a France side who had led by 12 points after just nine minutes.

RED CARD! Vahaamahina sees red after an elbow on Aaron Wainwright. Don't think there can be any complaints with that. France down to 14.#RWC2019 #ITVRugby #WALvFRA pic.twitter.com/fHTsfbwGTh — ITV Rugby (@ITVRugby) October 20, 2019

‘I thought France have definitely improved a lot since the Six Nations. They had some good structure today,’ Gatland added.

‘Losing becomes a habit but so does winning and we’re in that winning habit at the moment.

‘They’re a good team with some quality players and we know the strength in depth they have in France.

‘But the important thing is we’re not going home tomorrow. We’re here for the next two weeks.’
description: Warren Gatland could not help but see the similarities between Wales' Rugby World Cup quarter-final victory over France and their 2011 exit from the same tournament.
